key_insight: Spiking neural networks can be configured to solve finite element method (FEM) linear systems directly, turning numerical simulation into low‑energy, event‑driven neural dynamics that converge to FEM solutions.
problem_solved: Conventional FEM solvers for PDEs are computationally and energy intensive (especially for large sparse systems and real‑time/edge use); this work provides a brain‑inspired alternative that reduces energy cost and enables parallel, event‑driven solution of FEM problems.
method: Map FEM discretization and stiffness/mass matrices onto spiking network connectivity so neuron voltages/ spike rates represent solution variables.

Exploit event‑driven spiking dynamics and local synaptic updates to iteratively converge to the linear system solution, replacing dense numerical iterations with sparse, asynchronous neural computation.
Demonstrate and profile implementation on neuromorphic hardware (or hardware‑aware simulation) to quantify energy, speed, and scalability benefits versus CPU/GPU solvers.
impact: Provides a pathway to energy‑efficient, parallelizable physics simulation suitable for real‑time and edge applications, and encourages co‑design of numerical methods with neuromorphic hardware for scientific ML and simulation workloads.
visual_elements: Schematic showing FEM mesh → matrix → mapped spiking network (nodes = neurons, edges = synapses).
Timeline/animation of spiking dynamics converging to the FEM solution (voltage/spike raster evolving to steady state).
Bar/line chart comparing energy and latency of CPU/GPU FEM solvers vs neuromorphic spiking solver across problem sizes.
Icon set: FEM mesh, spiking neuron, neuromorphic chip, and energy meter to summarize takeaways at a glance.
paper_title: Solving finite element methods with spiking networks
paper_authors: Wenhao Song, Zixu Wang, J. Joshua Yang
